Literature Review:
The Rational Speech Act (RSA) framework has revolutionized the field of pragmatics by providing a comprehensive and integrated approach to understanding meaning in language. This literature review aims to provide an overview of the basic mechanics and commitments of RSA, as well as its standard extensions, highlighting the key features that have led to its success in accounting for a wide variety of pragmatic phenomena. We will also discuss the key challenges faced by RSA, including scalability, the treatment of the boundedness of cognition, and the incremental and compositional nature of language.

Probabilistic pragmatics, which RSA is a part of, has gained significant attention in recent years due to its ability to integrate insights from formal and experimental semantics and pragmatics, psycholinguistics, and computational cognitive science (Brewer & Hardcastle, 2010). RSA is a probabilistic approach to pragmatics that treats language as probabilistic, informativeness as gradient, alternatives as context-dependent, and subjective prior beliefs (world knowledge) as a crucial facet of interpretation (Kempe & Hampe, 2007).

One of the key features of RSA is its ability to provide an integrated account of the link between production and interpretation. This is achieved through the use of a probabilistic model that takes into account the speaker's prior beliefs, the context, and the listener's prior beliefs (Hampe & Kempe, 2007). This model allows for the prediction of the speaker's intended meaning and the listener's interpretation of the message.

RSA has been successful in accounting for a wide variety of pragmatic phenomena, including the interpretation of implicatures, the use of modal verbs, and the expression of degrees of belief (Kempe & Hampe, 2007; Brewer & Hardcastle, 2010). However, RSA also faces several challenges, including scalability, the treatment of the boundedness of cognition, and the incremental and compositional nature of language.

One of the key challenges faced by RSA is scalability. As the complexity of the language increases, the number of possible interpretations grows exponentially, making it difficult for RSA to account for all possible meanings (Hampe & Kempe, 2007). To address this challenge, RSA has been extended to include more sophisticated models of cognition and inference (Brewer & Hardcastle, 2010).

Another challenge faced by RSA is the treatment of the boundedness of cognition. RSA assumes that the speaker and listener have unlimited prior knowledge, which is not the case in reality (Hampe & Kempe, 2007). To address this challenge, RSA has been extended to include models of bounded cognition, which take into account the limitations of human knowledge (Brewer & Hardcastle, 2010).

Finally, RSA faces the challenge of the incremental and compositional nature of language. Language is composed of a series of words and phrases that are combined to form sentences, and the meaning of the sentence is determined by the relationships between the words and phrases (Hampe & Kempe, 2007). RSA has been extended to include models of incremental and compositional processing, which take into account the way in which language is processed incrementally and compositionally (Brewer & Hardcastle, 2010).

In conclusion, RSA is a powerful framework for understanding meaning in language. Its ability to integrate insights from formal and experimental semantics and pragmatics, psycholinguistics, and computational cognitive science has led to its success in accounting for a wide variety of pragmatic phenomena. However, RSA also faces several challenges, including scalability, the treatment of the boundedness of cognition, and the incremental and compositional nature of language.
